Overview:
This mobile redesign reimagines the Domino’s ordering experience with a sharper, more intuitive user flow and a bold flat-UI aesthetic. Created as a class assignment, it became a passion project driven by my love for improving everyday digital experiences. The goal was simple: fix the frustrating UX of the existing app and make pizza ordering fast, clear, and visually cohesive.

I rebuilt the entire design system from the ground up with clean, modular components, defined states, and a flexible variable structure supporting light and dark modes. The color palette was reinvented for vibrancy and contrast, while typography stays confident yet readable. Every interaction, from micro animations to modal transitions, was refined to feel responsive and satisfying.

The new flow dramatically reduces the number of steps to browse the menu, build a pizza, and check out. Features like guest checkout and simplified navigation remove friction while keeping the brand’s personality intact. I validated improvements through peer feedback and user testing, iterating based on real behavior.

It’s a complete end-to-end Figma prototype that feels modern, efficient, and cohesive from screen to screen, a redesign that makes ordering pizza actually enjoyable.

Overview:
Deployed as Overtone, this mobile-first drum-tuning companion was prototyped and designed in Figma, then coded in TypeScript/JavaScript, HTML, and CSS and hosted on Vercel. I built it to replace an older tuner that I stopped maintaining, with the goal of having something I trust for daily practice and gigs. The interface supports light and dark modes for studio and stage, and the app runs as a fast single-page experience so it feels instant on phones. An embedded test link is available in my portfolio so you can preview the live build below.

At its core is a Hz mic pickup written in JavaScript using the Web Audio API that listens through the device mic and detects the fundamental in real time. A locking system holds the reading once the pitch stabilizes so fine adjustments are easy and the value does not jump around. A Settings page lets you dial in detection behavior with sensitivity, noise gate, averaging window, min and max Hz, A4 reference, and input device selection. You can create kits with named drums, sizes, targets, and saved last-locked values so moving around the kit is quick and consistent. The main tuner view keeps focus with a large frequency readout, note mapping, peak hold, clear Live and Locked states, and simple cues that work in noisy rooms. Continuous deploys keep the embedded demo current while I iterate on per-lug workflows and quick session presets.

I designed Velkro, a modular display typeface built entirely from geometric shapes on a strict grid, then showcased it in a finished event poster and a documented process book. The poster—titled “Older Than Dirt”—tests the face at scale with bold, blocky forms, clear hierarchy for venue/date details, and an earthy green palette anchored by an orange accent. The process book traces the build from research and sketching into grid construction, drawing, spacing/kerning, and refinement of key glyphs (W, Q, K, J, R, D), using an orange-cream visual system and texture studies to echo the project’s material theme. Together, the artifacts show how Velkro evolves from modular parts into a usable type system, and how it performs in real layout, color, and print contexts.

Deployed and in daily use at Packanack Golf Course, this project delivers a member-only mobile experience and a desktop staff console with role-based authorization in Neon PostgreSQL; built primarily in TypeScript (95%) with supporting Java/HTML/CSS, hosted on Vercel, and synced in real time via Firebase for presence, messaging, and state. 

Commissioned after the club’s website rework, I designed and delivered the full flow for tee-time booking, event/tournament registration, and turn-aware food ordering (pickup, cart delivery, or at the turn). Staff operate a live, no-refresh dashboard where orders, tee sheets, and check-ins stream through Firebase listeners and Vercel APIs, while Postgres permissions gate each station’s tools: the kitchen advances tickets (Received → In Prep → Ready), cart staff mark En Route/Delivered, and the pro shop approves or adjusts tee times and pairings—instantly reflected to members and written to Postgres for audit/reporting. Highlights: a tee sheet with conflict detection, drag-to-reschedule, bulk weather-delay actions, and course/day/hole filters; food ordering with prep-time estimates, throttle controls, and a color-coded queue; and events with registration caps, waitlists, one-tap check-in, scoring exports, and live reporting—an experience that feels instant for members and like a control room for staff.

Led a ground-up redesign to modernize the club’s legacy site. I rebuilt the front-end in lightweight, accessible HTML/CSS, simplified navigation, and introduced flexible sections for the course, family activities, dining, PGA instruction, and a live events calendar. To bring the experience to life, I produced new photography and a drone flyover. The result is a fast, responsive site that feels current while keeping the club’s character (yes, there’s a playful footer-logo hover Easter egg).

Halfway Construction is a tongue-in-cheek brand for the crew that “never quite finishes”—built to feel playful and anti-corporate. I developed a bold safety-inspired palette (traffic-cone orange, caution yellow, deep charcoal) with hazard-stripe accents and a modular logo that snaps into flexible badges, stickers, and site headers. The identity leans on chunky, construction-grade geometry and witty microcopy to keep the satire front and center. I also produced motion tests—an animated hazard-stripe loader, a bouncy cone mark, and a snappy logo build—to bring personality to web and social. The result is a tight, production-ready system that reads small-brand friendly, instantly recognizable, and delightfully “under construction.”

Overview: I researched the Adelle type family and wrote a critical essay on its voice, versatility, and slab-serif construction, then translated that research into a cohesive publication. I produced two editions: a black-and-white version that spotlights rhythm, spacing, and pure typographic contrast, and a color version using a warm red/cream palette for wayfinding, section markers, and tone. Building both pushed my editorial skills, baseline grid, modular scale, column architecture, while dialing in micro-typography (hierarchy, measure, leading, tracking, optical alignment, hyphenation/rags, widow/orphan control). The result is a readable, research-driven book that shows Adelle across weights and sizes and demonstrates my growth in layout systems and publication design.

Octone Ink is a tattoo-ink brand inspired by the purity and protective nature of octopus ink—built for artists who value safety and sustainability. I led the identity from sketchbook to system: dozens of thumbnail studies and form explorations, narrowed through iterative rounds before finalizing in Illustrator. The mark is engineered with the golden ratio—an abstract octopus constructed from golden circles—to achieve balanced geometry and instant recognizability. A clean wordmark, ratio-driven spacing, and an eco-leaning palette extend seamlessly across labels, web, and merch. The result is a production-ready identity that communicates “Unleashing nature’s purest ink” with precision, craft, and credibility.

Recognition: Published in The Monmouth Review 2024

I founded and owned SageAIO, a private retail-commerce automation app created during COVID to help users secure limited-stock drops for personal buys or high-margin resale before they sold out. I launched the product solo, covering strategy, branding, UI/UX, front-end engineering, PR and graphics, customer support, and Heroku deployments. As traction grew, I hired backend developers to maintain services, increase reliability, and meet demand while I continued to lead product and design.

SageAIO shipped with a cohesive dark UI and gradient accents across a complete suite: a Home dashboard with real-time analytics, a Tasks hub for high-volume task groups, Profiles for payment and shipping, a Proxies manager for IP rotation, and Settings with license-key auth, auto updates, and advanced toggles. Discord webhooks delivered instant status and success notifications. Memberships were intentionally capped, yet we served 100+ paying users and built a loyal community on X at @SageAIO. The project concluded when I returned to school, and it ended on great terms with customers reporting strong profits and a brand and UI that outperformed much larger competitors.

Squisito is a mobile app for Italian-food lovers to share recipes and tutorials. It was one of my first college UI projects and the spark for pursuing design. I built a reusable design system with a consistent 8-pt spacing scale, tight grid, and predictable margins and padding across screens. Typography follows a clear hierarchy, and the color palette stays cohesive across light accents and dark text for readable contrast. Components are modular and repeatable, including cards, buttons, inputs, tabs, and recipe tiles with defined states for hover, focus, loading, and errors.

I went all in and produced a fully functional Figma prototype that covers end-to-end flows: upload, discovery, profiles, search and filters, and detailed nutrition with macros. It feels polished, fast, and consistent from screen to screen. View the linked prototype at the bottom of the project page.

Recognition: Published in The Monmouth Review 2023

Overview: Two companion shorts exploring journey and motion, built frame-by-frame in Stop Motion Studio. The first follows a lone planet drifting through a starry field toward connection, using deep indigo and soft white accents for a calm, spacey tone. The second distills movement to rhythm and form with a monochrome blue palette and looping shapes that build energy. Together, they pair narrative and abstraction with consistent layout, tight framing, and steady pacing for a clean, cohesive look.

I built a city identity system from research through final assets. I selected Tokyo and captured its mix of tradition and neon modernity through mood boards, visual audits, and type studies. The system starts with a clear grid and an 8-pt spacing scale, plus a classic red and blue palette for high contrast and instant recognition. I designed a cohesive icon set (landmarks, food, transit, culture), then extended the look into banners, postcards, and a UI kit for a travel app with cards, tabs, and maps. Typography follows a strict hierarchy for wayfinding and accessibility checks ensured readable color contrast. Everything shares consistent margins, padding, and component states so print and digital feel like one brand.
Scroll the project to see the full case study and the linked prototypes.

A color and mood study from a college photography course. I built a simple in-studio rig: a mirror as the base, a neon light placed over it, and a rotation of reflective materials to bend and multiply the glow. By changing angles and distance, the reflections created layered gradients that echo the pull of the Northern Lights. I shot on a Canon and finished in Adobe Lightroom, dialing contrast and color harmony while keeping the in-camera effects intact. The result is a tight series that draws the viewer in with luminous reflections and clean, graphic compositions.

In this Adobe Illustrator study, I recreated Rechnitz Hall using only geometric shapes and gradient shading. The challenge was to reduce real-world architecture to clean vector forms while preserving depth, light, and material cues. I established a perspective grid, blocked the building into simplified planes, and used controlled light-to-dark gradients to model volume and cast shadows with precision.

My Drawing I fundamentals guided value structure and edge control, which I then translated into a crisp digital workflow. The project strengthened my command of vector illustration, gradient-based rendering, and architectural simplification. The first image is my vector recreation; the second is the original reference.

Recognition: Published in The Monmouth Review 2024

Concert poster for Sunscape Valley. I built a warm desert scene with layered gradients and soft grain: ochre sky, peach–coral sun, mauve-violet mountains, and a small cactus for scale. The arced wordmark uses stretched psychedelic letterforms, while the lineup sits in a clean grid with corner date badges for quick scanning. The palette leans sunset and sand—apricot, coral, dusty rose, and deep plum—for a nostalgic, heat-haze vibe. Type hierarchy, margins, and bleed-safe edges were tuned for large-format print and social crops. See the full-size poster on the sunscape-poster page.

I reimagined U.S. currency through a Fender guitar lens, pairing legendary artists with their signature models. The set assigns a distinct, bill-specific palette for instant recognition: amber gold for the Telecaster ($50, Bruce Springsteen), crimson red for the Jazzmaster ($20, Kurt Cobain), moss green for the Starcaster ($5, Radiohead’s guitarist), and violet–lilac for the Stratocaster ($100, Jimi Hendrix). Each note uses a modular grid, bold denomination hierarchy, and an oversized guitar silhouette as a watermark shape.

Security-inspired detailing elevates the system: microprint patterns, mirrored numerals, serial indicators, and a vector Fender headstock emblem used as a repeating mark. Layered textures, controlled grain, and opacity masks blend photography with vector forms without muddying type. The result is a cohesive, high-contrast series that feels like real currency while celebrating rock history through color, typography, and meticulous print craft.

I designed my personal identity system starting with a custom AF monogram. The mark unites a triangular A with the F carved out in negative space, creating a sharp peak that reads as both initial and directional arrow. From that foundation I built a compact system: primary and stacked lockups, a repeating monogram pattern, and clear spacing rules on an 8-pt grid. The palette is deep navy with crisp white accents for professional contrast, plus light geometric line work that echoes the logo’s angles. Applications include a navy tee with vertical name treatment and corner bug, business cards featuring the tiled pattern back, and a signage mockup with clean typographic hierarchy. Consistent margins, alignment, and color ensure every piece feels like one brand.

A cohesive iOS widget and icon pack built around a space motif. I established a modular grid with consistent corner radii, stroke weights, and padding so every glyph feels related. The visual language leans on orbits, radar rings, and soft planetary gradients. The palette pairs deep navy and teal bases with a sci-fi green glow to pop on dark wallpapers. Set includes a UFO “Find My” beacon, orbital rings for Fitness, a lunar Weather tile, a radar-style Maps icon, Podcasts, and a clean analog Clock. Designed through rounds of sketching and iteration, then redrawn in Illustrator using reusable components and exported at multiple sizes. The result is polished, readable, and ready for daily use.

One of my first end-to-end app designs and a great marker of my growth. I built Tracker as a dark-themed productivity hub that centralizes reminders, tasks, appointments, and light stats. The home screen uses color-coded tiles for quick scanning, backed by a strict 8-pt spacing system, consistent corner radii, and a clear type hierarchy. I created a reusable component library in Figma with Auto Layout, variants, and defined states for hover, active, success, and error. Core flows include onboarding, creating and organizing lists, scheduling items, and reviewing progress. The result is a fully clickable prototype that feels polished and coherent across screens, clean, legible, and ready for daily use.

A four-piece collage series that blends hand work with digital craft. I built physical compositions from textured papers, foil, and found imagery, then scanned everything at high resolution. In Photoshop I curated the fragments, established a clean grid, and unified the set with a green-led palette—emerald, chartreuse, moss, and aqua. Masking, blend modes, controlled opacity, and subtle grain preserved paper tooth and edge detail, while vector accents in Illustrator added crisp planetary geometry and alignment. Final prints were prepared with consistent margins and color profiles for gallery presentation.

Recognition: Published in The Monmouth Review 2023

A minimalist poster for Whiplash built around rhythm, tension, and control. I used a strict grid and bold display letterforms to split the title into two punchy blocks WHIP and LASH! so the type itself feels percussive. Diagonal drumsticks and a cymbal silhouette cut across the frame to suggest motion and timing. The palette channels brass and stage light: warm amber–gold gradients against near-black for high contrast and drama. Careful kerning, generous margins, and bleed-safe edges keep the layout razor clean, while subtle grain adds cinematic texture for print. The result is a striking, restrained composition that captures the film’s precision and intensity without a single wasted element.

Before college I’d barely drawn and was honestly nervous about it. Studying classical methods at Monmouth changed that fast. I learned a disciplined process, gesture to block-in, measuring and sighting, grouping values, and controlling edges, using charcoal and sanguine on toned papers. Each session started with a light lay-in and plumb lines, then massed shadow shapes, lifted lights with a kneaded eraser, and finished with confident accents in compressed charcoal and sanguine. Across figure, skull, and still-life studies, you can see the progression from tentative marks to clear proportion, believable light, and purposeful line. This work turned drawing from a fear into a foundation I now bring to everything else I design.
